sen.j: 八ツ橋（やつはし）は、和菓子のひとつ。
sen.e: Yatsuhashi refers to one of the Japanese-style confectioneries.
Yatsuhashi refers to one of the Japanese-style confectioneries.
Yatsuhashi refers to one of the Japanese-style confectioneries.
Yatsuhashi is a well-known confectionery originated in Kyoto City.
Yatsuhashi is a well-known confectionery originating in Kyoto City.
Yatsuhashi is a well-known confectionery originating in Kyoto City.

sen.j: 表記は、八橋、八つ橋、八ッ橋とも。
sen.e: It is written 八橋, 八つ橋 or 八ッ橋.
It is written 八橋, 八つ橋 or 八ッ橋.
It is written 八橋, 八つ橋 or 八ッ橋.

sen.j: 上新粉（米粉）、砂糖、ニッキ（肉桂・シナモン）の粉末を混ぜて生地を作り、薄く焼き上げたせんべいの一種で、形は箏を模しており、長軸方向が凸になった湾曲した長方形をしている。
sen.e: Yatsuhashi is a kind of thin rice cracker that is made by baking the dough consisting of joshinko (komeko) (high-quality non-glutinous rice powder), sugar and cinnamon powder that has been rolled out thin and cut into the shape of koto (a long Japanese zither iwth thirteen strings), which is a rectangle convexly curved symmetrically to the longer axis.

Yatsuhashi is a kind of thin rice cracker that is made by baking the dough consisting of joshinko (komeko) (high-quality non-glutinous rice powder), sugar and cinnamon powder that has been rolled out thin and cut into the shape of koto (a long Japanese zither iwth thirteen strings), which is a rectangle convexly curved symmetrically to the longer axis.

Yatsuhashi is a kind of thin rice cracker that is made by baking the dough consisting of joshinko (komeko) (high-quality non-glutinous rice powder), sugar and cinnamon powder that has been rolled out thin and cut into the shape of koto (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings), which is a rectangle convexly curved symmetrically to the longer axis.

sen.j: 聖護院八ツ橋総本店による製品で、別に橋を模しているという説もある。
sen.e: Yatsuhashi is made by Shogoin Yatsuhashi Sohonten and some argue that it is in the shape of a bridge.
sen.cmt: 「聖護院八ツ橋総本店」は店の名称で固有名詞なので、そのままにしてあります。
sen.e: Yatsuhashi is made by Shogoin Yatsuhashi Sohonten and some argue that it is in the shape of a bridge.
Yatsuhashi is made by Shogoin Yatsuhashi Sohonten and some argue that it is in the shape of a bridge.

sen.j: 焼かずに蒸しあげたものは生八ツ橋（なまやつはし）と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Yatsuhashi that is steamed and not baked is referred to as Nama-yatsuhashi (unbaked yatsuhashi)
sen.cmt: 「生八ツ橋」の定義は'raw yatsuhashi' を訂正して'unbaked Yatsuhashi'としてあります。
sen.e: Yatsuhashi that is steamed and not baked is referred to as Nama-yatsuhashi (unbaked yatsuhashi)
Yatsuhashi that is steamed and not baked is referred to as Nama-yatsuhashi (unbaked yatsuhashi).

sen.j: 創業三百年を超える老舗としては、本家西尾八ッ橋が、知られている。
sen.e: Honke Nishio Yatsuhashi that is a long-established store founded over 300 years ago is well known.
sen.cmt: 店の名称は固有名詞ですので、そのままにしてあります。
sen.e: Honke Nishio Yatsuhashi that is a long-established store founded over 300 years ago, is well known.
Honke Nishio Yatsuhashi that is a long-established store founded over 300 years ago, is well known.

sen.j: 昔の生八ツ橋は竹皮によって包まれていたが、現在は賞味期限を延ばすためにほとんどが真空パック詰めされている。
sen.e: Nama-yatsuhashi used to be wrapped in takegawa (husk of bamboo shoots) but, today, they are predominantly vacuum-packed to improve its shelf life.
sen.cmt: 「竹皮」は竹の子の皮。定訳不明 http://www.harusato.jp/bamboobark/index.html, 「賞味期限を延ばすため」の訳はto delay the best before date (to postpone the best before date) から'to improve the shelf life of the product' に訂正しました。
sen.e: Nama-yatsuhashi used to be wrapped in takegawa (husk of bamboo shoots) but, today, they are predominantly vacuum-packed to improve its shelf life.
Nama-yatsuhashi used to be wrapped in takegawa (husk of bamboo shoots) but, today, they are predominantly vacuum-packed to improve its shelf life.

sen.j: そのため、開封しなければ賞味期限はおおよそ9〜11日となっている。
sen.e: The shelf life of unopened nama-yatsuhashi is now approximately 9 to11 days.
sen.cmt: 「開封しなければ賞味期限は・・・」は北米での一般的な表現に修正しました。
sen.e: The shelf life of unopened nama-yatsuhashi is now approximately 9 to11 days.
The shelf life of unopened nama-yatsuhashi is now approximately 9 to 11 days.

sen.j: 名前の由来は伊勢物語の九段「かきつばた」の舞台となった「三河国八ツ橋」の故事にあるという説と、八橋検校の名にちなんで箏の形を模したことに由来する説とがある。
sen.e: There are 2 different explanations as to where the name Yatsuhashi came from with one being 'Yatsuhashi in the Mikawa Province', which the story was set in the ninth chapter of the Tale of Ise 'Kakitsubata (water irises)' and with the other being it was made into the shape of koto after Kengyo Yatsuhashi.

There are 2 different explanations as to where the name Yatsuhashi came from with one being 'Yatsuhashi in Mikawa Province,' where the story was set in the ninth chapter of the Tale of Ise 'Kakitsubata (water irises)' and with the other being it was made into the shape of a koto after Kengyo Yatsuhashi.

There are 2 different explanations as to where the name Yatsuhashi came from with one being 'Yatsuhashi in Mikawa Province,' where the story was set in the ninth chapter of the Tale of Ise 'Kakitsubata (water irises)' and with the other being it was made into the shape of a koto after Kengyo Yatsuhashi.

tit.cmt: 「あん入り」は'sweet red bean filled' に訂正しました。

sen.j: 生八ツ橋でつぶ餡を包んだ『あん入り生八ツ橋』は、その後改良が加えられ、現在見られる生八ツ橋の形態となった。
sen.e: "An-iri nama-yatsuhashi (nama-yatsuhashi filled with coarsely mashed sweet red beans)" has subsequently gone through numerous improvements prior to settling on the present form.
"An-iri nama-yatsuhashi (nama-yatsuhashi filled with coarsely mashed sweet red beans)" has subsequently gone through numerous improvements prior to settling on the present form.
"An-iri nama-yatsuhashi (nama-yatsuhashi filled with coarsely mashed sweet red beans)" has subsequently gone through numerous improvements prior to settling on the present form.

sen.j: 通常京都では「おたべ」が八ツ橋と呼ばれることはない。
sen.e: In Kyoto, 'Otabe' is never referred to as Yatsuhashi in general.
In Kyoto, 'Otabe' is never referred to as Yatsuhashi in general.
In Kyoto, 'Otabe' is never referred to as Yatsuhashi in general.
Umean (sweet white bean paste with plums)
Umean (sweet white bean paste with plums)
Umean (sweet white bean paste with plums)
Baked sweet potato jam Kyoto style
Baked sweet potato jam Kyoto style
Baked sweet potato jam Kyoto style

sen.cmt: 「うぐいすあん」は鶯豆のあん。'Sweet green pea paste' に訂正しました。

sen.j: 統計調査によると京都観光のみやげとして菓子類を購入をする人は96%にのぼるが、そのうち八ツ橋の売上は全体の45.6%（生八ツ橋24.5%、八ツ橋21.1%）を占め、京都を代表するみやげ物と言える。
sen.e: According to a survey, 96% of visitors buy confectioneries as momento of their trip to Kyoto and of the 96%, the sales of yatsuhashi make up for 45.6% (24.5% for nama-yatsuhashi and 21.1% for yatsuhashi) whereby it can be said that yatsuhashi is a representative souvenir item of Kyoto.

According to a survey, 96% of visitors buy confectioneries as momento of their trip to Kyoto and of the 96%, the sales of yatsuhashi make up for 45.6% (24.5% for nama-yatsuhashi and 21.1% for yatsuhashi) whereby it can be said that yatsuhashi is a representative souvenir item of Kyoto.

According to a survey, 96% of visitors buy confectioneries as memento of their trip to Kyoto and of the 96%, the sales of yatsuhashi make up for 45.6% (24.5% for nama-yatsuhashi and 21.1% for yatsuhashi) whereby it can be said that yatsuhashi is a representative souvenir item of Kyoto.

tit.j: 八ツ橋を販売している主な企業

sen.e: Product names are shown in the parethesis
Product names are shown in the parethesis
Product names are shown in the parentheses

sen.j: 聖護院八ツ橋総本店（聖・ひじり）
本家西尾八ッ橋（あんなま）
白心堂（あんさん、粋都・すいーつ）
御殿八ッ橋本舗（おぼこ）
sen.cmt: 「御殿八つ橋本舗」は店の名称で固有名詞ですから、そのまま'Goten Yatsuhashi Honpo' また「おぼこ」も同店の製品名なので、そのままにしました。

sen.j: 聖光堂八ツ橋總本舗（なまやつ）
sen.cmt: 「御殿八つ橋本舗」は店の名称で固有名詞ですから、そのまま'Goten Yatsuhashi Honpo' また「おぼこ」も同店の製品名なので、そのままにしました。
